title: The Levite's Tragedy
shortSummary: Judges 19 recounts a harrowing and tragic episode during a time when Israel had no king, highlighting the moral decay and lawlessness of the period. The chapter tells the story of a Levite and his concubine, whose mistreatment in the town of Gibeah leads to a shocking act that shocks all Israel. This narrative sets the stage for national crisis and calls for reflection on justice and righteousness.
timeline: c. 1200 BC - Period of the Judges in Israel, before the establishment of monarchy

keyCharacters.name: Levite
keyCharacters.description: A Levite sojourning on the side of Mount Ephraim who takes a concubine and whose journey triggers the tragic events in Gibeah.

keyCharacters.name: Concubine
keyCharacters.description: The Levite's concubine who leaves him, returns to her father's house, and suffers brutal abuse in Gibeah.

keyCharacters.name: Damsel's Father
keyCharacters.description: The concubine's father who hospitably receives the Levite and urges him to stay longer before his departure.

keyCharacters.name: Old Man of Gibeah
keyCharacters.description: A resident of Gibeah who offers hospitality to the Levite and his party, but is powerless to protect them from the wicked men of the city.

definitions.definition: A woman who lives with a man but has lower status than a wife; often without the full rights of a wife.
A Hebrew term meaning 'worthlessness' or 'wickedness,' often used to describe lawless or evil men.
Food or fodder for animals, such as hay or grain.
Temporarily residing or living in a place without permanent settlement.

outline.heading: The Levite and His Concubine's Departure
outline.description: The chapter opens with the Levite's concubine leaving him to return to her father's house. After four months, the Levite goes to reconcile with her, and they stay several days before setting out together toward home.

outline.heading: Journey to Gibeah and Seeking Shelter
outline.description: As evening falls, the Levite and his party approach Gibeah but find no one willing to offer lodging until an old man invites them into his home, demonstrating hospitality amidst a corrupt environment.

outline.heading: The Atrocity Committed Against the Concubine
outline.description: The wicked men of Gibeah surround the house and demand to abuse the Levite. To protect himself, the host offers his daughter and the Levite's concubine, who is brutally abused throughout the night, highlighting the depravity of the time.

outline.heading: The Aftermath and Call to Action
outline.description: The concubine returns to the Levite, dies, and he dismembers her body, sending the pieces throughout Israel as a call for justice. The chapter closes with a solemn reflection on the unprecedented wickedness witnessed.

application: Recognize the dangers of moral decay and the importance of godly leadership and obedience to God's law to prevent societal collapse.
Practice hospitality and compassion, but remain vigilant against evil and stand firm in righteousness.
Respond to injustice with prayerful action and seek godly counsel to address sin and restore justice.
Reflect on personal responsibility to uphold biblical standards and promote holiness in the community.

keyVerses.text: And it came to pass in those days, when there was no king in Israel, that there was a certain Levite sojourning on the side of mount Ephraim, who took to him a concubine out of Bethlehemjudah.
keyVerses.significance: This verse sets the historical context of lawlessness and introduces the main characters, highlighting the need for godly leadership.

keyVerses.text: Behold, here is my daughter a maiden, and his concubine; them I will bring out now, and humble ye them, and do with them what seemeth good unto you: but unto this man do not so vile a thing.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the depth of depravity and the tragic compromise of innocence to protect self, illustrating the moral crisis.

keyVerses.text: And when he was come into his house, he took a knife, and laid hold on his concubine, and divided her, together with her bones, into twelve pieces, and sent her into all the coasts of Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This shocking act serves as a call to all Israel to confront the evil and restore justice, emphasizing the gravity of sin.

keyVerses.text: And it was so, that all that saw it said, There was no such deed done nor seen from the day that the children of Israel came up out of the land of Egypt unto this day: consider of it, take advice, and speak your minds.
keyVerses.significance: This closing verse challenges the nation to reflect on the consequences of their sin and to seek repentance and restoration.
